data.text: Road Pedals vs MTB Pedals for Long-Distance Bikepacking

On very long rides or bikepacking expeditions, are there any opinions on this group concerning the use of road vs. MTB pedals? I'm a road rider so used to road pedals but I figure if I'm on a bikepacking expedition where I might go offroad or have to walk at some points MTB might be a better bet? And are MTB pedals, which are smaller, still comfortable to ride on during long rides that last several hours? Any feedback to share?
SPD cleats would best serve you while bikepacking, if you were to use clipless. Or flat MTB pedals.
data.author: Dean Wolfgang

data.text: In my bikepacking experience, there is always some pushing. Pushing up a hill that's too steep, crossing creeks... But I do all of my bikepacking in the back country. I actually prefer flat pedals, so that I can wear a comfortable shoe that's easy to hike in.
data.author: Matthew Hall

data.text: what shoes? I find many mtn bike shoes (necessarily) have very stiff soles that make hiking rough.
data.author: Brian Frasca

data.text: just my sneakers.
data.author: Matthew Hall

data.text: Going off road and bikepacking is always better on SPD pedals, better pedaling than on flats and easier to walk than road pedals. If you come from road riding I guess you'll get used to them easily.
data.author: Sebasti√† Perell√≥

data.text: I have ridden as as long as 24 hrs straight on spd. 200 miles of dirt in one ride. No problems with spd. And of course multi day multi hundred mile dirt tours without spd problems.
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: Wide flat pedals are my friend.
data.author: Todd Wehrenberg

data.text: I prefer flats for many reasons. For bikepacking I like wearing a shoe that works for hike a bike or just being more comfy at camp and not having to bring another pair log shoes.
data.author: Wade Patterson

data.text: *pair OF shoes. Not sure what log shoes are.
data.author: Wade Patterson

data.text: Clipless mountain bike shoes and pedals like Crankbrothers Mallet series. The shoes are great for walking and the pedals have a nice platform. https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/2256/0503/t/49/assets/mallet-ready-to-ride.png?v=16936050174418663875
data.author: John Sandlin

data.text: I have been riding spd pedals on mountain and road/gravel bike for years. Makes the shoe choices easy
data.author: Mike Booth

data.text: I went to flat pedal on all my bikes maybe four years
data.author: James Madden

data.text: If you must clip in then MTB pedals are way more suitable. Particularly if you get some of the downhill / enduro style ones with a large flat platform around the mechanism. Road clips are solely focussed on efficiency on the bike. That‚Äôs not what bike packing is about. You‚Äôll have a terrible time with road pedals. A lot of people like the crank bros mallet DH or Mallet E. They have a lot of float which I personally hate (I ride flats with 5:10s & when you put your foot down it does not move a mm) but they are nicer on your knees on longer rides & easy to get in & out of than shimanos. Probably more important is shoes. You don‚Äôt want a super hard soled cross country race style shoe as they‚Äôre a bitch to walk in. You may not fall over as much as in a road shoe but you don‚Äôt want to walk far in them. Again the shoes that are more aimed at the downhill segment would be more suitable. I imagine you‚Äôd find the leisure shoes too flexible coming from road riding but some of the DH shoes are pretty stiff but still have a recessed cleat & a sole pattern with actual rubber, rather than hard plastic. The Specialized f20 clips are good as are a lot of the five ten models.
data.author: Tim Williams

data.text: I saw something a little while back from Lael Wilcox about how she was using/going to use road pedals. Might be worth checking into ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
data.author: Ben Meyer

data.text: Spd for me. I put pedals on that have one flat side so if I run into peanut butter mud that cakes my cleats on my Great Divide tour I can use flat side.
data.author: Bobbie Gullickson

data.text: I see no reason to use road pedals outside of racing. In the real non race world you will need to walk at some point and wearing shoes that make that not only difficult but sometimes treacherous makes no sense. Recessed SPD cleats, pedal and shoes are absolutely fine/comfortable for all day use. Even my minimalist XTR race pedals get used all day with no issue. I use MTB style pedals on all my bikes including road bikes. The key to comfort is not pedals etc, but shoes that fit you properly, so they are comfortable for long days and have good support over the pedal, but flex otherwise.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: You can bet you‚Äôll end up walking on a bikepacking trip, maybe just to ‚Äúreboot the hard drive,‚Äù maybe full-on bushwhacking. Shimano SPD‚Äôs and an MTB shoe are a good way to go.
data.author: Justin M Short BA

data.text: +1 for mtb pedals when bike packing. Having shoes you can walk in is key :)
data.author: Dave Cohen

data.text: I'd recommend the Time Speciale 8 pedals. or if you want a pedal that is spd/flat combo crankbrothers Doubleshot 3.
data.author: Carlos Asenvader

data.text: Mtb pedals. Spd trail have a bit of a platform as well
data.author: Sandy Maxwell

data.text: You really want that platform to avoid a ‚Äúhotspot‚Äù / pressure point on your feet after extended hours Get touring specific shoes, I like the one with laces versus boa clips
data.author: Philip Yates

data.text: , not necessarily, I have platform and XC race XTR pedals and zero hot spot issues. That problem is more down to the shoe than pedal design. I definitely prefer laces over boas. Never found a boa shoe I could get to fit as comfortably. Usually because they don't snug you in enough higher up foot, so heel can lift.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: I‚Äôve found that with good insoles, I don‚Äôt get the hotspots. But I do prefer laces.
data.author: Skeevi Strauss

data.text: No pedals just push bike like Flintstones
data.author: Richard Bergh

data.text: MTB pedals for safety reasons on unknown terrain. Also, less likely to cause problems if your shoes get caked with mud.
data.author: Alain Mendo√ßa

data.text: MTB pedals. One less pair of shoes to haul.
data.author: Sean McLenidoodle

data.text: I use mtb shoes and clipless pedals. Wouldn't cycle without them. Don't buy cheap, but good quality ones are comfy to ride in and easy when you want to walk, pop onto a shop etc.
data.author: Gogs Nichol

data.text:
I like spd and flat pedals but if I had to choose between road and mtb clipless for bikepacking, then always spd pedals. Eventually some infos for you: https://youtu.be/ykU99jLIFgg
Road Or MTB Pedals - Which Should You Choose?
youtube.com
data.author: Silvio Schl√∂ffel

data.text: I used mtb clip less pedals and shoes all the time, way more comfortable to walk in them even for a quick stop at the shop and avoid looking like a duck
data.author: Paolo Capozzi

data.text:
I use SPD on my gravel bike with the tension backed out for easy unclipping, and flat pedals on my MTB bike just because I prefer that. Does any one run fixie style foot straps on flat pedals? I saw one of the Bikepacking.com guys with it them in a video or photo but no discussion. I‚Äôd consider it if I knew there‚Äôd be lots of hike a bike or river crossings so that I could wear good walking shoes.
BIKEPACKING.com - Bikepacking Routes, Gear, Inspiration
bikepacking.com
data.author: Nam Tr·∫ßn

data.text: i wore road pedals for 11,000 miles on a trip around the u.s. i was fine with it. havent tried anything different for that long. i switched into my easily accessible slides whenever i had to walk or be off the bike extensively
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: I moved to flat pedals last year and won't go back no decrease in speed and really super happy in the change
data.author: Eric Cummins

data.text: I always use mountain pedals. Never had a problem with hot spots
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Love my crank bother candy‚Äôs
data.author: Fran Morgan

data.text: Well there are definitely opinions, haha.
data.author: Skeevi Strauss

data.text: I've used SPD for ever and they've served me well. However, when I cycle in cold weather on an all day ride, SPD pedals remove all the heat from my feet. For this reason, I'm planning on switching to flat pedals. I'm sure I'll have better & more generic shoe options with flat pedals and as a result, much warmer feet.
data.author: Paul Martindale

data.text: I use dual sided pedals with SPD MTB shoes. When I bomb down a bumpy road I can bounce off the pedals. When I spin through mud or slowly go uphill I like to be un-clipped, it only takes one or two pedal rotations to fall over. I have found that broad platform pedals without spikes, or whatever they call them, can let my shoe slip off them when wet. Much of what we use should be predicated on where we ride, the conditions we ride in, our abilities, and our aversion to risk. I personally hate falling over when I can't unclip and didn't see something coming (once a rapidly approaching dog). Likewise having your foot bounce off a pedal on a fast, bumpy descent is no fun either. YMMV
data.author: Chuck Perry

data.text: Mt bike rider. Bikepacking is off road for the most part. Bike paths, dirt roads, singletrack. Flat pedals and sandals work well for me.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: I prefer flats, because I always seem to do a lot of walking and I have really wide feet.
data.author: Chuck Thibault

data.text: Trail running shoes and flat mtb pedals are my go-to for bikepacking trips. There is always a fair amount of hike-a-bike sections in the mountains especially with the extra weight of camping gear on the bike.
data.author: Daren Eaken

data.text: I use hybrid spd pedals so I can clip in, but also ride it wearing my regular sneakers.
data.author: Anouk Verhoeks

data.text: Running flats and wearing the shoes for it is so much more comfy if needing to walk than spd shoes
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text:
Mtb pedals clear mud much better and are easier to walk in. When changing pedals take into consideration that difference pedals can have different stack height. Take a measurement from the top of your pedal to the top of your saddle in line with the seat tube angle (ie, the max leg extension point). Note this measurement, swap pedals, apply the measurement. You may have to raise (most likely with road to mtb) or lower your saddle height. All of this is to keep your leg extension/flexion the same. Next you want to notate your current cleat placement and transfer those measurements to your new shoes/cleats. This is a bit more complicated so I'll refer you to; http://wobblenaught.com/mtbsample.asp Look to the cleat placement instructions mid way down.
Wobble Naught online and custom bike fitting - fits for road & mountain bike - laser measurement system - dealer & coach certification
wobblenaught.com
data.author: Eddie O'Dea

data.text: I ran SPDs for a long time (20 or so years) but recently switched to Time ATAC XCs due to knee issues. I'll never go back to SPDs. I get far better blood flow throughout my legs and feet and my knees follow a more natural path throughout my pedal stroke. Just got back from 240 miles on the Great Allegheny Passage (GAP trail) over 2.5 days. They worked flawlessly.
data.author: AJ DeLauder

data.text: Men flat on one side so if camped or need to dry road shoes that I have also recessed cleats as well .. on touring and road bikes
data.author: Patrick J McDonald

data.text: I‚Äôm also a road rider, & when I started bikepacking I used SPD pedals & shoes that could clip in but were still comfortable to walk around in rough ground. Then I switched to Pedals that I could use the SPD‚Äôs on 1 side, or flip to flats on the other side, but I didn‚Äôt like them because they didn‚Äôt always flip To either the spd or the flat side, so I had to look down every time I started peddling. I ended up switching to MTB flat pedals for bikepacking & that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm sticking with, as its so much easier on rough terrain‚Ä¶& I can peddle from camp to the grocery store in my camp shoes (crocs)!
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: I just got in an overnighter using Bontrager Avert 'adventure' shoes. They click into my MTB pedals, yet off the bike flex & walk like a hiking shoes. Road shoes are light & efficient but are awkward off the bike
data.author: Mike Kehoe
